awd_titl_txt: REU Site: EXERCISE - Explore Emerging Computing in Science and Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
The project is a renewal of the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) EXERCISE (Explore Emerging Computing in Science and Engineering) site at Salisbury University (SU) for the next three years. EXERCISE is an interdisciplinary project that explores emerging paradigms in parallel computing with data and compute intensive applications in science and engineering. The goal of the project is to offer student participants, particularly from primarily undergraduate institutions (PUIs), a valuable research experience in parallel computing. The project will promote "parallel thinking", an important computational thinking skill guiding current generation students into the twenty-first century computing era. The site will prioritize recruiting under-represented students and females, and attract students from local historically black college and universities (HBCUs), PUIs, and community colleges on Maryland's Eastern Shore into computational science and engineering majors and the general Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) fields. The Principal Investigator, together with faculty mentors, will supervise a 10-week REU program that gives a diverse cohort of students a taste of computational thinking in the domain of parallel computing and also an understanding of the graduate school experience. The host institution SU will collaborate with the University of Maryland Eastern Shore, an HBCU, and the University of Maryland College Park for multi-disciplinary faculty expertise and diverse summer activities including field trips, social activities, high school outreach, and graduate school application information sessions.

Processing complex information and large data in conventional von Neumann computer architectures is becoming increasingly difficult. Computers are undertaking a fundamental turn toward concurrency architectures such as hyperthreading, multi-core, and many-core architectures. Emerging parallel and distributed computing paradigms adapted to these concurrent architectures have begun to demonstrate the power of solving problems with large datasets and high computational complexity in a wide range of applications. However, there are fundamental difficulties in program semantics related to process interleaving: a parallel program can yield inconsistent answers, or even crash, due to unpredictable interactions between simultaneous tasks. Secondly, communication, memory access, and I/O overhead may result in run-time delays. Finally, it is difficult to ensure that programs consume resources in a manner that simultaneously achieves efficiency and meets performance goals. The REU Site will focus on four aspects of parallel computing, namely: algorithms, software, architecture and applications to address these parallel computing challenges. Students will work with faculty mentors in completing cutting-edge research projects to tackle data and compute intensive applications that emphasize the above four aspects. By the end of program, students will acquire valuable skills, gain a broader and deeper understanding of research, and develop greater confidence in their abilities. In particular, they will be exposed to emerging paradigms in parallel computing such as Map-Reduce and Graphical Processing Unit computing, and will have opportunities to explore concurrent software and multiprocessor architectures, and design efficient parallel algorithms, and to tackle data and compute intensive problems in computer and social networks, image and natural language processing, pattern recognition and machine learning.

por.por_cntn:
The REU site: "EXERCISE - Explore Emerging Computing in Science and Engineering" (Feb 2018 - Jan 2022) has provided valuable research experiences in high performance computing (HPC) to a total of thirty undergraduate students and helped them build confidence in research and develop problem-solving skills. During the summer research program, students applied emerging parallel computing models such as GPU computing with NVIDIA CUDA (a local parallel processing system) and MapReduce computing on clusters (a distributed parallel processing system) to tackle data and compute-intensive problems in computer networks and security, image and signal processing, and natural langue processing.

The REU site placed recruiting efforts on woman and underrepresented minorities, particularly students from historically black college and universities (HBCUs) and primarily undergraduate institutions (PUIs) with limited research resources and opportunities. The application data reveals that the application pool consists of over 29% females, 18% African Americans, 9% Hispanic/Latinos, and 1% Native Americans/American Indians. The total number of applicants of last three years is 159, where 68% of applicants are from PUIs with limited research resources and 56% are belong to underrepresented minority groups. The REU student participants were over 23% (=7/30) females, 13% (=4/30) African Americans, 3% (=1/30) Hispanic/Latinos, and 3% (=1/30) Native Americans/American Indians. Notably, there were over 73% (=22/30) REU participants from outside of our REU site home school and 83% (= 25/30) from PUIs and HBCUs including Wheaton College, Truman College, Grinnell College, Bridgewater College, Wellesley College, Pomona College, Swarthmore College, The College of New Jersey, Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology, Eastern University, Georgia College and State University, Jackson State University, and University of Maryland Eastern Shore.

The REU project assessment showed that the overall experiences for the REU participants were rewarding. Students indicated that the REU program provided a rich learning environment and met or exceeded their expectations. Particularly, the students' experiences of the summer research, field trips, and the REU program in general were very positive. Students were pleased with the teamwork, on-campus living, frequent progress reports, and interaction with faculty members. The results that used both the matched pairs' t-test for mean difference and the Wilcoxon Signed-Rank test for median difference obtained from the post-survey compared to the pre-survey suggested that the students had significant gain in their perceived knowledge about research after the REU experience! The REU students commented: "The overall process was rewarding for me because I learned new subjects independently for the first time in terms of a research background. This REU has given me insight as to what it will take to be a researcher in the future...Really helped me to see the importance and joy (and struggles!) of conducting research...Group bonding was good! Researchers were easy to hang out with. It was pleasant and wonderful experience...It was a great and rewarding experience, despite the ongoing Covid situation...Really enjoyed my REU experience this summer... All our needs were met!"

The REU project results were well disseminated. All REU students presented their summer projects at the SU's Henson Summer Research Program Symposium. Some of them have been selected to present their research projects at IEEE/ACM International Conference for High Performance Computing, Networking, Storage and Analysis (Supercomputing), SPIE Scientific Sensing and Imaging Conference, SPIE Conference on Computational Imaging, Anniversary National Conference on Undergraduate Research (NCUR), National Workshop for REU Research in Networking and Systems, Emerging Researchers National Conference in STEM, and SU Annual Student Research Conference. The REU site has generated ten publications in which REU students were the leading authors from the project summer research program. The PI was invited to serve on both Program Committees for the Seventh National Workshop for REU Research in Networking and Systems (REUNS 2021) and 2021 National Symposium for NSF REU Research in Data Science, Systems, and Security. The PI was also featured on "What It's Like To Be An Asian American Woman In STEM Today" on Bustle in 2019 and was nominated for the Salisbury University Outstanding Research Mentor Award in 2021.

The REU EXERCISE project has broader impacts on multiple communities including encouraging undergraduate students to pursue graduate studies and professional careers in computing; providing valuable education and research resources for PUIs and HBCUs with limited computing research facilities; sparking local high school students' interests in science and engineering careers and having positive influence on regional workforce development; successfully promoting "parallel thinking", an important computational thinking skill, among current generation students and attracting more students to future careers in STEM areas.

 

The project website is available at http://faculty.salisbury.edu/~ealu/REU/REU.html.
